biography: Ferenc Krausz is a Hungarian physicist working in attosecond science. He was a director at the Max Planck Institute of Quantum Optics and a professor of experimental physics at the Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich in Germany. His research team generated and measured the first attosecond light pulse and used it for capturing electrons' motion inside atoms, marking the birth of attophysics. In 2023, jointly with Pierre Agostini and Anne L'Huillier, he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics. Since November 2025, he has been Chair Professor at Department of Physics in The University of Hong Kong, Pokfulam, Hong Kong.

### 3. Key Procedures & Clinical Expertise

Dr. Krausz's expertise in Biomedical Optics likely encompasses a wide range of diagnostic and therapeutic applications. One area of likely expertise is Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT). Dr. Krausz likely utilizes OCT extensively in ophthalmology to diagnose and monitor conditions such as macular degeneration, glaucoma, and diabetic retinopathy. He may also apply OCT in other medical specialties, such as cardiology (to image coronary arteries) or dermatology (to image skin lesions).

Another area of potential expertise is confocal microscopy. Confocal microscopy is a technique that uses lasers to create high-resolution images of thick tissue samples. Dr. Krausz may use confocal microscopy to study cellular and subcellular structures, identify cancerous cells, or monitor the effects of drug treatments.

Laser-based therapies likely form a significant part of Dr. Krausz's clinical practice. He might perform laser surgery to remove tumors, cauterize blood vessels, or reshape tissues. He could also use lasers for photodynamic therapy (PDT), a treatment that uses light-sensitive drugs to kill cancer cells. Furthermore, Dr. Krausz likely possesses expertise in fluorescence imaging. Fluorescence imaging is a technique that uses fluorescent dyes to label specific molecules or structures within cells or tissues. He might use fluorescence imaging to track the movement of cells, detect the presence of pathogens, or monitor the activity of enzymes.
